column4: hi guys.. i am getting really bad wlan speeds.. just around 200 kb/p it should be in MBs right...  any idea why so?? i am on ubuntu 10.10
magic_ninja,  yes i have a win xp machine as well..
i have a 600 kbps internet line that goes to my linksys router.. and from there i get wifi to my ubuntu box
is there some setting on the linksys router that curbs the data transfer between 2 comps of the network
i am using samba share.. to share files.. and while copying from one comp to another.. its barely 200 kbps.. instead of MBs
how fast is it when you copy using HTTP or something else?
try installing+starting apache, then copy a file to your docroot (with default apache it's /var/www). Download this file over the network (default would be http://your-ip-address/filename.ext)
and how would installing apache help me ???
sudo apt-get install apache2 && sudo service apache2 start
no i know that part... i meant.. how will it help me
oh. well, if the download is faster over HTTP, then you know it's not your network card/driver but samba
or rather, you have a strong indication. it can still be the network card/driver
i feel it could be my wireless router .. :S ... how do i check that for a linksys router.. noob here
type and paste the output of "iwconfig"
http://pastie.org/1509801

hmm. you have a pretty low quality, though still good bit rate. it might be that the samba protocol is struggling over that connection/router. try changing the buffer sizes. check rsize and wsize in "man mount.cifs". it's mount options
No manual entry for mount.cifs
also: sudo apt-get install smbfs
installed that
anything else to install??
then you have mount.cifs' man page
just type: man mount.cifs
no luck
